novel_text:
The light was a clean, white scalpel. It sliced through the hushed dimness of the spare bedroom, pinning a single, struggling point of life to a square of polished obsidian. Under the unforgiving glare of the articulated lamp, *Formica rufa*, the red wood ant, soldiered on, its antennae twitching in a frantic semaphore of confusion and alarm. Tonya watched, her breath a slow, controlled tide in her chest. Her world had shrunk to this two-inch stage, this tiny drama of one. She wore no mask, but her face was as serene and immobile as a surgeon’s. Love required stillness. It demanded precision.

She’d followed this one for two days. A magnificent specimen. The slight, almost imperceptible asymmetry in its gaster, the subtle russet shading on its thorax—it was perfect in its imperfection. It was worthy. He would have liked this one. He would have spent an hour explaining its caste, its pheromonal language, the sheer evolutionary miracle of its existence. Tonya did not need the lecture anymore. She had absorbed it all, letting his knowledge colonize her, a new and sacred biome in the empty space he’d left behind. Now, she was the curator of his passion.

Her fingers, gloved in powder-free nitrile, moved with the unthinking grace of a concert pianist. She selected a pair of tweezers whose tips were ground to a near-molecular thinness. With a movement too swift for the ant to register, she nudged the tiny glass cloche covering it, creating a space just wide enough. The second instrument was a single human hair, plucked that morning, glued to the end of a delicate rod. She dipped its tip into a waiting bead of liquid glistening on a glass slide. Aconitine, extracted with painstaking effort from a single Wolf’s Bane plant she cultivated in a black pot on her windowsill. It was a poison of myth. A poet’s poison. It was fitting.

The ant, sensing the shift in air pressure, surged for the gap. Tonya was ready. The hair-tip applicator met the ant’s antenna in a kiss of shocking intimacy. The creature froze. A tremor, a violent, microscopic shudder, ran the length of its segmented body. Its legs, so full of frantic purpose a moment ago, curled inward. It was over. The stillness that followed was profound, a vacuum. Tonya felt it in her own lungs. She held her breath with the deceased, a shared, final exhalation.

Then, the second act. The art. She carefully transferred the tiny corpse to a block of black velvet, the same used by jewelers to display their finest solitaires. The posing was the most difficult part. It took an hour. Micro-forceps, stainless steel pins no thicker than a nerve ending, a magnifying visor that lowered over her eyes like a knight’s helmet. She worked to arrange it not in a posture of life, but in a posture of offering. Its head was tilted, its legs arranged in a pattern of submission. And then, the lips. She preferred the term ‘lips’ to ‘mandibles’. Mandibles was a cold, chitinous word. Lips were for kissing, for speaking, for tasting. With a tool of her own design, a tiny lever of sharpened dental wire, she gently, reverently, parted them.

The camera, a hulking Canon with a macro lens the size of a fist, was already in position. She leaned in, her eye to the viewfinder. The world vanished. There was only this. The alien, terrifying, beautiful architecture of the ant’s mouth. The serrated inner edges, the delicate palps, the textures invisible to the naked eye. It was a secret world. A world only she and he could ever truly appreciate. She adjusted the focus by a micron. The silence in the room was a held breath, waiting for a fever to break.

Click.

The shutter’s report was a soft, final punctuation. On the camera’s screen, the image bloomed. A landscape of dreadful intimacy. She had captured it. The essence. The last, silent word spoken from those lips. Another photograph for the collection. Another testament to a love so large it had to be expressed in the smallest of deaths.

From his non-place in the back corner of a Spokane library, the one on South Lincoln Street, DI Tales watched the image upload. It appeared on the photostream he monitored, a fresh wound among the old. The username was ‘SymmetryForJ.’ The photo was titled ‘Red Word.’ He felt the familiar, phantom chill, the one that had been his only constant companion for what felt like a lifetime. He was a doctor, or had been. He saw the world in terms of diagnosis. This was not art. This was a symptom.

The living moved around him like fish in a current he could not feel. A young woman with headphones on, her expression slack-jawed, walked through the space his left arm occupied. He felt nothing, of course. There was no substance to be disturbed. He was a draft of memory in a room full of warm bodies. He had long ago stopped flinching. His focus was absolute. He zoomed in on the image, not with a mouse and keyboard, but with a simple act of will. The picture filled his perception, a universe of texture and shadow.

‘SymmetryForJ.’ Tonya, he called her. He didn’t know her real name, but she felt like a Tonya. Solid, grounded, with a hint of Slavic tragedy in her bones. He’d built a profile in the empty chambers of his mind. Female, late 30s. Solitary. Highly intelligent, patient. Grieving. The ‘J’ was the key. J was the ghost she was trying to appease. The recipient of these macabre love letters.

Tales had been a diagnostician. He looked for patterns. At first, it was just the ants. Common Lasius niger. Then, the species began to diversify. Pavement ants. Carpenter ants. Now, Formica rufa, the red wood ant. The geography of her collection was expanding. The technique was improving, too. The early kills were clumsy, the carapaces sometimes crushed. Now, they were flawless. She was perfecting her craft. A surgeon honing her technique. The thought made the air in his non-lungs feel thin. Doctors, good ones, understood that a disease left untreated would metastasize. It would seek a larger host.

He had died on a Tuesday. A pulmonary embolism, silent and swift as an assassin. One moment he was complaining to his nurse, Martha, about the hospital’s dreadful coffee, the next he was… observing. Watching his own body slump in his chair, watching the panic, the futile CPR, the pronouncement. He had been a man of science and substance. He was now a hypothesis, a ghost story. And the most frustrating part of his condition was the impotence. He was a detective who could not lift a fingerprint, a doctor who could not touch his patient. He could only watch. And worry.

He sifted through the data of the new photograph. She was getting bolder. The background of ‘Red Word’ was not the familiar polished obsidian. It was a piece of dark, rough-hewn wood. He willed the image to expand again, focusing on a sliver of the background. He could make out the grain. The unique, swirling pattern of a burl. Oak, maybe? And in the corner, a tiny detail she would have missed. A watermark. A faint, almost invisible stamp. A logo. He couldn’t quite make it out. It was a circle with something inside. A bird? An initial?

He felt a surge of something that might have once been adrenaline. It was a lead. A tangible connection, however faint, to the physical world where she operated. He had to identify that mark. He had spent his life, his real one, solving puzzles inside the human body. This was no different. He was simply looking for the source of the infection. He had to find Tonya. He had to understand the shape of her love, the architecture of her grief. He had to stop her before she decided that ants were no longer enough. Before she looked for a larger vessel to hold all her terrible, beautiful devotion. The library was closing. The lights flickered once, a signal to the living. The patrons began to pack their bags, their movements solid and sure. Tales remained, a silent sentinel in the gathering dark, staring at a picture of a dead ant’s lips, feeling the cold, inexorable certainty that he was the only one who knew a storm was coming.The janitor, a man named Gary whose weary slouch Tales had memorized like a medical chart, made his final round. His keys jangled a lonely, metallic tune as he locked the main doors, plunging the library into a cathedral-like quiet. For the living, the building was now empty. For Tales, it was finally his. He drifted from his corner, a silent eddy in the still air, and returned his full consciousness to the image of ‘Red Word.’ The physical screens had long since gone dark, but the image was seared into his perception, a slide under the microscope of his mind.

He pushed against the photograph, an act of pure will that had no physical correlation but felt like leaning into a strong wind. The watermark. The circle with the bird inside. The grain of the wood was a landscape of ridges and valleys, a topography he could almost feel. It was oak, he was almost certain, and the specific pattern was from a burl, a chaotic knot of growth that created the most beautiful, most unpredictable grains. J, the man for whom all this was done, must have appreciated such things. An appreciation for the complex beauty born from trauma and deviation. It was all of a piece. The imperfect ant, the burl wood, the grief that twisted love into this meticulous, murderous art.

His impotence was a physical ache, a phantom limb where his entire body used to be. In life, he would have been on the phone, delegating. He would have had a junior detective running license plates, an intern cross-referencing databases. He would have had his hands on the problem, palpating it for weaknesses. Now, he was reduced to this. A spectator, waiting for the world to bring him the clues he needed. The logo was a question he could not type into a search bar. He was a consciousness trapped in a bottle, and the entire internet, the greatest library in human history, was on the other side of the glass. He could only wait for someone else to turn the page.

* * *

After the final click, Tonya dismantled her world with the same reverence she had used to build it. The hulking Canon was powered down, its lens cap replaced with a soft thud. The tiny, posed corpse of the ant was transferred from the velvet block into a small glass-topped specimen box, which she labeled in a precise, architectural script: *Formica rufa, #27, Red Word*. It joined the others on a shelf in a temperature-controlled cabinet, a growing congregation of tiny martyrs. Each box was a votive, a prayer rendered in chitin and formaldehyde.

She stripped off the nitrile gloves, turning them inside out and sealing them in a small bag. Her tools were wiped down first with alcohol, then with a sterile cloth, before being laid back in their velvet-lined case. The tweezers, the micro-forceps, the hair-tip applicator, her custom-made mandible-lever—they all rested in their form-fitting depressions, an arsenal of delicate violence. The obsidian square and the velvet block were polished and put away. The last piece to be moved was the block of burl wood. She ran her bare fingers over its chaotic, swirling grain. J had given it to her. It was a cheese board, meant for brie and prosciutto and gatherings with friends. A lifetime ago. He’d bought it from a craftsman at a weekend market downtown. ‘Look at the grain, Tonya,’ he’d said, his voice buzzing with the excitement he found in the details of the world. ‘It’s like a map of a storm.’ Now, it was a stage. A beautiful, scarred landscape for her tragedies of one.

Her small apartment was a testament to a life distilled to its essentials. Clean, spartan, a single black pot on the windowsill where the Wolf’s Bane grew, its purple flowers a splash of royal poison against the grey Spokane sky. She didn’t eat here, not really. She didn’t entertain. She worked. She remembered. And she curated. She sat at her small desk and pulled up the photostream for ‘SymmetryForJ.’ She looked at ‘Red Word’ not as a photograph of a dead insect, but as a message sent into the ether. A message for an audience of one, who she knew could never see it. The intimacy of the image was the only way she could scream. The silence of her apartment was the only space vast enough to contain the echo.

* * *

The sun rose, casting long, dusty fingers of light through the library’s tall windows. The sounds of the city returned: the distant growl of traffic, the squeal of a bus’s air brakes. Then came the rattle of Gary’s keys, and the living began to trickle back in. Tales watched them, a current of purposeful bodies flowing around his stationary island of nothingness. A student, panicked about a deadline, raced to the history section. A homeless man, seeking warmth, settled into a carrel with a newspaper. A young mother steered her toddler towards the colourful promise of the children’s wing. They were all closed loops, preoccupied with their own narratives.

Tales drifted, a disembodied observer, his focus a hunter’s. He needed a specific kind of prey. Someone curious. Someone with a connection to craft, to wood, to local commerce. He floated behind a man in a flannel shirt who was poring over schematics for deck construction. For a moment, Tales felt a flicker of hope, but the man’s search was purely practical, his queries filled with terms like ‘load-bearing’ and ‘pressure-treated.’ He was not looking for art. Tales moved on. He had all the time in the world, a fact that was both a comfort and a curse. His own life had been a frantic race against the clock, against the progress of disease. Now, he was suspended in an endless, agonizing waiting room.

It was well past noon when he found her. A young woman with dark-rimmed glasses and a silver stud in her nose. She sat at a terminal in the reference section, surrounded by books on Pacific Northwest art. Her posture was studious, her brow furrowed in concentration. Tales positioned himself behind her, his non-physical form perfectly placed to see her screen. She was writing a paper, the title at the top of the document read: ‘From Totems to Tables: The Enduring Spirit of PNW Artisanship.’ He felt it again, that ghost of adrenaline. This was it. She typed, her fingers flying across the keyboard. Her search query was a gift from a god he no longer believed in: “local Spokane woodcraft artisans.” A page of results bloomed on the screen. A list of names and businesses. Tales scanned them, his focus narrowing. And then she clicked on a link. The website loaded, and the logo appeared, crisp and clear in the top left corner. A perfect circle. And inside, a stylized bird—a wren, he now saw—with its head cocked, its beak forming the cross-bar of a capital ‘B’. Below it, the words: ‘Burl & Beak Woodcraft.’ He had it. He had a name. It was a tangible piece of the world, a pin dropped on a map. For the first time since he had died, DI Tales had a destination. Now he just had to find a way to get there.The library was a cage, elegant and quiet, but a cage nonetheless. For weeks, or months—time had become a viscous, unreliable fluid—Tales had accepted its boundaries as the limits of his new reality. The world outside the tall arched windows was a silent film he could observe but not join. But now, with a name and a logo burned into his mind, the library’s familiar silence felt like a suffocating pressure. ‘Burl & Beak Woodcraft.’ It was a location. A place of substance and sawdust, a place where Tonya had been. To a ghost, a physical coordinate was an impossible, taunting dream.

His attention snapped back to the young woman with the dark-rimmed glasses. She was his only chance. He watched as she saved her document, closed the browser tabs, and began to gather her belongings with the unhurried movements of someone whose day was winding down. A canvas tote bag, a dented metal water bottle, a worn copy of a book on forestry. Each item was a solid, real thing, a piece of a world he could no longer manipulate. She was his vessel, his unwitting ferryman. He had to try. He had spent his first life diagnosing the frailties of the human body; he would spend his second diagnosing the physics of his own dissolution.

He marshaled his focus, a power he was only beginning to understand. It felt like holding his breath and flexing a muscle that wasn't there. He concentrated everything he was, his memory, his worry, his fading identity, into a single point of intention aimed directly at her. As she slung the tote bag over her shoulder and began to walk towards the main exit, Tales pushed off from his corner, not moving through the air so much as willing himself to be adjacent to her. He felt a strange, elastic pull, as if he had become a satellite caught in the faint gravitational field of her life force.

The automatic doors slid open with a soft hiss, and the student stepped out into the late afternoon light. Tales followed, and the world exploded. For the first time since his death, he was outside. The sensory onslaught was a physical blow. The muted, dusty air of the library was replaced by a riot of smells: hot asphalt, diesel exhaust, the sweet, cloying scent of a flowering bush nearby. The quiet hum of the library’s HVAC system was annihilated by the roar of a passing bus, its immense vibration passing through his formless state like a shockwave, leaving him feeling frayed and scattered. The sunlight was not the gentle, slanted beam he was used to, but a brilliant, brutal glare that seemed to make his own transparency shimmer and thin.

He fought to hold on. The pull to the student, his anchor, was the only thing that kept him from dissolving entirely or snapping back to the safe, dead quiet of the library. He was a kite in a hurricane, and she was the hand holding the string. She put her headphones on, oblivious, and crossed at the light, her head bobbing to a beat he couldn't hear. A cyclist swerved around her, and for a terrifying second, passed directly through Tales. The rush of kinetic energy and the fleeting, phantom sensation of a living, straining body was so alien, so overwhelming, that his concentration wavered. The world flickered, and for a half-second, he saw the familiar shelves of the library’s biography section superimposed over the moving traffic. He clamped down with his will, the effort a silent scream. The street solidified around him again.

He was a parasite of perception, clinging to her as she walked west on Main Avenue. He didn't know where ‘Burl & Beak’ was. His knowledge of the city was a static memory from a life that felt increasingly like someone else’s. He couldn't ask for directions. He couldn't pull a phone from a pocket that didn't exist and look at a map. He could only follow this oblivious stranger and pray that her path would bring him within range. He scanned the storefronts they passed, his gaze sweeping over coffee shops, boutiques, and law offices. He was hunting for a sign, a logo, a breadcrumb. He was a detective again, but his beat was now the crowded, chaotic streets of a city he could only haunt, chasing the ghost of a woman who was still very much alive.The student, his unwitting Charon, navigated the downtown grid with the aimless drift of someone with time to kill. For Tales, every step was a gamble. He had to learn the rules of this new state of being on the fly. He discovered that a crowd was a nightmare, a chaotic mass of life forces that threatened to pull him in a dozen different directions at once, diluting his will. He learned that proximity was key; if she got more than thirty feet ahead of him, the tether stretched thin and taut, and the safe, oppressive silence of the South Lincoln Street library would begin to hum at the edges of his perception, a siren call back to his cage. He was a deep-sea diver on a fragile air hose, and the library was his bell jar on the surface.

She paused to look in the window of a bakery, her attention caught by a pyramid of glazed lemon tarts. Tales drifted beside her, the phantom scent of sugar and browned butter a cruel memory. Through the glass, he watched a family laughing, a small boy smearing chocolate on his cheek. They were so vibrant, so solid. He felt a profound, hollow ache that had nothing to do with a body. It was the grief of being an annotation in the margin of a book everyone else was still living. The student, deciding against the tart, moved on, and Tales was pulled along in her wake, relieved and resentful in equal measure. Her simple, mundane choices were the arbiters of his fate.

Her path took her away from the main thoroughfare and onto a quieter street of brick-fronted buildings, where the chain stores gave way to independent shops. Art galleries, a custom frame store, a shop selling hand-bound journals. The air here felt different, less frantic. It felt closer. Tales scanned every sign, every doorway, his focus a desperate searchlight. The student was walking with more purpose now, as if her destination was near. And then he saw it. Not where she was headed, but down a narrow intersecting lane she was about to pass. It was a modest sign, a disc of dark wood hanging from an iron bracket, swaying slightly in the breeze. On it, expertly carved, was the logo from the website. The wren, the circle, the elegant script beneath: *Burl & Beak Woodcraft*.

It was a moment of pure, clinical triumph, followed immediately by a surge of panic. His anchor, the student, was not turning. She was walking straight past the lane, her headphones a barrier to any plea he could never make. He could feel the distance growing, the tether stretching. Ten feet. Fifteen. The library hummed louder in his non-existent ears. He had a choice, and he had only a second to make it. He could stay with the safety of his living host, follow her wherever she was going, and hope he could find his way back to this spot another day, another week, another lifetime. Or he could let go. He could sever the connection and attempt the fifty-foot leap to the shop on his own, with no idea if his consciousness could survive such a transit untethered. It was the difference between a chronic condition and an acute, potentially fatal, event.

He made the choice a doctor makes when the conservative treatment has failed. He cut. With a final, desperate act of will, he focused everything he was—the sum of his memories, his methodical mind, the full weight of his concern for the unknown Tonya—on the wooden sign. He let go of the student. The sensation was terrifying, an abrupt and total disconnection. The world dissolved into a meaningless roar of sensory data. Light, sound, and motion blended into a nauseating, colorless storm. He was unmoored, a ghost in a hurricane, his very identity threatening to fray and shred into nothing. He was no longer observing the world; he was being consumed by it.

Then, impact. Not physical, but existential. His fragmented perception slammed into a new focus and solidified. The chaotic noise of the street vanished, replaced by a profound, woody silence. He was inside. The air, if he could have breathed it, was thick with the clean, sharp scent of sawdust and the deeper, resinous perfume of tung oil. He had made it. He was in a small, beautifully curated showroom. Sunlight streamed through the front window, illuminating the intricate grains of finished furniture: a dining table with a live edge that flowed like a river, a set of chairs whose backs curved like human spines, shelves laden with bowls and cutting boards of every shape and size. It was a gallery of captured nature. And on a display stand near the back, he saw it. A stack of round oak burl cheese boards, their surfaces a maelstrom of swirling, chaotic patterns. One of them was missing. One of them was in Tonya’s spare bedroom, serving as a stage for her tiny, perfect deaths. He was at the source.The workshop was a sanctuary of potential. Unlike the library, which was a repository of finished thoughts and closed histories, this place hummed with a silent, vibrant future. Half-finished chairs stood like skeletal promises, and massive slabs of raw, uncut lumber leaned against one wall, their bark still clinging like old memories. They were books waiting to be opened, stories waiting to be told. Tales drifted through the space, his formless state allowing him to pass through a workbench cluttered with chisels and hand planes, their steel edges gleaming under the dusty light. He felt a sense of profound, almost professional respect for the order within the chaos. This was a different kind of operating theater.

He came to a stop before the display stand. He focused on the stack of cheese boards, identical in shape but each one a unique universe of pattern. The wood grain swirled like cream in dark coffee, like weather patterns seen from space, like the intricate pathways of a neural network. He understood why J had been drawn to them, and why Tonya had chosen one as a stage. It was a beautiful scar. A geological event frozen in time. He ran his perception over the top board, imagining the weight and texture, the faint drag of its polished surface. He was a connoisseur of patterns, and this was a masterpiece of organized chaos, so much like the diseases he used to hunt.

A door at the back of the showroom creaked open, and a man emerged from the dust-filled workshop beyond. He was broad-shouldered, in his late fifties maybe, with a thick grey beard that had captured a fine gilding of sawdust. He wore a heavy canvas apron over a faded flannel shirt, and his hands, as he wiped them on a rag, were wide and calloused, but moved with a surprising delicacy. He exuded a quiet, grounded energy, the polar opposite of the city's frantic pulse. This was the craftsman. The creator.

The man, oblivious to his spectral visitor, walked over to a magnificent walnut desk that was clearly his own handiwork. He grunted softly, a sound of satisfaction, as he picked up a small, hand-carved wren from its surface and blew a stray speck of dust from its wing. He then turned his attention to a tablet mounted on a wooden stand. With a swipe of a thick finger, the screen came to life. Tales drifted closer, his entire being constricting into a tight knot of focus. This was it. The point of access. The archive.

The craftsman tapped through several screens, his movements methodical. He was checking sales figures, cross-referencing them with an inventory list. Tales watched, a silent phantom hovering over his shoulder. The screen showed lists of items, prices, dates. It was a stream of raw data he was powerless to navigate himself. He could only wait, a beggar at the window of a banquet, hoping a scrap of information would be dropped. The man’s finger hovered over a file labeled ‘Spokane Weekend Market – Sales.’ Tales felt the phantom charge of adrenaline again. J had bought the board at a market. This was the right vein.

The man opened the file. A list of transactions appeared, dated a little over a year ago. It was a long list, a successful weekend. The craftsman scrolled slowly, his brow furrowed slightly as he reconciled the numbers. Tales’s perception devoured the screen, scanning names and item descriptions. *Cedar Box. Walnut Bowl. Cherry Spoon Set.* He saw names—Miller, Chen, Rodriguez—a litany of the living, the solid, the people who could buy things and take them home. He searched for a Tonya, a T., anything. Nothing. The craftsman was nearing the bottom of the list. A cold dread, the familiar feeling of a dead end, began to seep into Tales.

Then the man’s finger stopped. He tapped on a line, expanding it. Item: *Oak Burl Round Board, 12”*. Date: a Saturday in late May. And there, under ‘Customer,’ was the name. It wasn’t Tonya. It was a simple, elegant entry: J. Alistair Finch. Below it was an email address. J.A.Finch@spokane.edu.

J. Alistair Finch. The ‘J’ was no longer a variable. It was a man. A man with a name, a man with an affiliation to the local university. The entire architecture of the mystery shifted, its foundation settling into something solid. J wasn't just a ghost Tonya was grieving; he was a person who had lived and worked and bought things in this very city. Tales felt a surge of elation so pure it was almost painful. It was a diagnosis. He had found the patient’s name on the chart.

The craftsman finished his task, locked the tablet, and returned to the tangible world of his workshop, the door closing behind him with a soft click. Tales was left alone in the silent showroom with the new, explosive piece of information. J. Alistair Finch. He repeated the name in his mind, engraving it into his memory. He had a name. It was the first solid thing he had held since he’d died. And like everything solid, it was completely out of his reach. He was still a ghost in a locked room, but now he knew the name of the man who had built the prison. His focus shifted from the craftsman’s shop to the wider world beyond the windows. Spokane University. It was another pin on the map, a place miles away. He had learned to jump, but it had nearly shredded him. Now, he had to figure out how to fly.The elation was a flash of heat, a magnesium flare that burned brightly for a moment before sputtering out, leaving behind the cold, grey ash of his reality. J. Alistair Finch. Spokane University. The information was a key, but he was standing on the wrong side of a locked and soundproofed door. The woodshop, once a thrilling destination, now felt like another room in his prison. Its quietude, once a relief from the street, was now the silence of a dead end. He had to move. The infection, he knew, was not centered here; this was merely a point of transmission. The true pathology was rooted in the life and memory of Professor Finch.

He drifted to the front window, his form shimmering in the afternoon sun. The lane outside was quiet, but at its mouth, the main street was a river of metal and intention. Cars, trucks, delivery vans—each a private, sealed container moving at impossible speeds. He had nearly disintegrated making a fifty-foot jump. A cross-town journey of several miles was unthinkable. Then he saw it. A city bus, long and articulated like some gentle, herbivorous beast, pulled to a stop a block away. Its doors folded open with a pneumatic sigh, disgorging a handful of people and swallowing a new group. It was a vessel. A public, mobile container full of the very life force he’d learned to use as an anchor. It wasn't one person he could lose, but a dozen he could cling to, a floating raft of souls. The plan formed in his mind with the swift, intuitive logic of a differential diagnosis. It was reckless, untried, and his only option.

Leaving the sanctuary of Burl & Beak was just as jarring as his first exit from the library. He braced himself, focusing on the bus as his target, and pushed through the window. The world rushed in again, a cacophony of roaring engines, distant sirens, and the sharp, unfiltered sunlight that made him feel thin and transparent. He fought the sensory overload, his will a thread stretched to its breaking point, and threw himself toward the bus just as its doors began to close. He passed through the glass and metal shell, the transition like a gasp of cold water, and found himself inside. The chaos of the street was instantly muffled, replaced by a low, vibrating hum and a dense, soupy atmosphere of human presence. The air was thick with stale perfume, damp coats, and the collective, low-grade anxieties and daydreams of two dozen strangers. He was a virus that had successfully breached the cell wall.

The journey was a new kind of vertigo. The world slid past the windows at a speed that felt both unreal and deeply unsettling, the familiar city rendered into a fluid blur. Tales anchored himself not to a single person, but to the general, ambient life of the bus itself. He felt the dull throb of a teenager’s bass-heavy music through her headphones, the weary frustration of a man who’d missed his stop, the quiet contentment of an elderly woman watching the world go by. He was awash in the mundane currents of their lives, a ghost on public transport, invisible, unnoticed, and more lonely than he had ever been in his silent library. He scanned the faces, the postures, the tired expressions, seeing them all with a clinician’s eye. A city of symptoms. The bus route, blessedly, angled toward the university district, and when he saw the grand, collegiate gothic architecture of the Spokane University gates loom into view, he felt a phantom relief so profound it was almost a physical sensation. As the bus sighed to a stop, he prepared himself and plunged back out into the world.

* * *

Tonya sat in the dimness of her spare bedroom, the sacred space. The photograph of ‘Red Word’ glowed on her monitor. It was, by all technical measures, perfect. The focus was flawless, the lighting dramatic. The offering was clear. And yet, it felt inadequate. A whisper when she needed a shout. Her love for J, his passion which was now her passion, was an immense, roaring thing. An ant, no matter how magnificent, no matter how poetically dispatched, felt like a single, insufficient syllable in a vast, complex language of grief. J had been a man who saw entire ecosystems in a single drop of pond water, who could discourse for an hour on the brutal elegance of a hornet’s sting or the iridescent shimmer of a dragonfly’s wing. He had taught her to see the universe in the small, and now her grief demanded she find a larger microcosm.

His perception swept the room—the microscope, the scattered research notes, the computer terminal left sleeping. And then he saw it. On the far workbench, under the soft glow of a utility lamp, stood a tall, mesh-sided enclosure. It was a new world, carefully constructed, and inside, perched on a piece of elegant driftwood, a living, breathing praying mantis was meticulously grooming its formidable foreleg.### Chapter 10

The laboratory was a sanctuary and a crime scene. To DI Tales, standing formless in its center, the small room was a complex tapestry of evidence. The primary exhibit was the mantis, Alistair, perched on a piece of elegant driftwood in its new, spacious enclosure. The meticulous construction of the habitat—the careful layering of substrate, the optimal placement of the branch—spoke with silent eloquence of Ben Carter’s character. He was a builder, a nurturer, a man who responded to a crisis by creating a better, safer world, however small. The sight of the living, thriving creature was a profound relief, a validation of the terrible risks Tales had taken. But it was also a source of deep, chilling dread. This enclosure was Ben’s confession. It was the physical manifestation of the secret that now isolated him, the secret that had made him Tonya’s new obsession. Tales understood with a veteran detective’s certainty that Ben had not simply taken the mantis; he had taken on Tonya’s entire pathology, and he was now carrying it alone.

Outside, in the bright, indifferent afternoon, Tonya watched the entrance to the coffee shop. She was a study in absolute stillness, a chameleon that had perfectly matched the color and texture of its surroundings. She registered the flow of students in and out of the building, the murmur of conversations, the clatter of skateboards, but it was all just atmospheric data, the background noise of her new specimen’s environment. When Ben finally emerged, his coffee untouched, his face a mask of pale, unresolved anxiety, she felt a flicker of something that was not emotion, but a cold, clinical satisfaction. The specimen was exhibiting signs of profound distress. Its routines were disrupted. Its social patterns were fractured. The introduction of a foreign variable—her—had produced a measurable, predictable result. She noted the information, filed it away in the vast, silent catalog of her mind, and waited to see where the distressed creature would seek refuge.

Ben could not sit still. The coffee shop, once a comforting wall of sound, had become an echo chamber for his own spiraling thoughts. He had to move. He had to *do* something. The only tangible focus he had, the only part of the preceding night’s madness that he could control, was the mantis. A sudden, urgent, and largely irrational thought seized him: the enclosure needed more ventilation. It was a flimsy pretext, a scientist’s rationalization for a deep, emotional need to return to the only place that felt remotely safe. He abandoned his table, dumped the full cup of coffee into a trash can with a sense of finality, and pushed his way back out into the bright, overwhelming world. His feet, acting on an instinct deeper than conscious thought, carried him back across the quad, back toward the Hall of Sciences, back to his lab.

As he moved, a shadow detached itself from the crowd. Tonya began her pursuit, a patient, methodical process that was the polar opposite of Ben’s frantic, headlong retreat. She kept a careful distance, using the shifting bodies of other students as moving screens. Her focus was absolute. She noted the way he clutched the strap of his backpack, the tension in his shoulders, the way he failed to deviate his path for an oncoming group, forcing them to part around him. Every gesture was a data point. Every action revealed a new facet of his compromised state. She was not just following him; she was dissecting him from afar, learning the rhythm of his distress, the architecture of his fear. She was the curator, and he was the beautiful, crooked thing she would soon collect.

Tales began to search. A being of pure will, untethered by gravity or solid matter, he moved through the building with the silent, relentless efficiency of a spreading gas. He swept through a bustling lecture hall where a professor droned on about mitochondrial DNA, the living minds a sea of boredom and concentration that he passed through like a cold front. He drifted through faculty offices, past professors arguing over grant proposals and staring at computer screens, their private dramas irrelevant to his singular, urgent mission. He was hunting for a specific psychic signature, the unique frequency of Ben Carter’s earnest, guilt-ridden consciousness. He could feel the ambient life of the building, a low, constant hum, but he was searching for a solo instrument in the orchestra, a single, identifiable voice in the choir.

The inevitable convergence came with a heart-stopping, silent near-miss. As Ben, fumbling with his keys, approached the door to his lab at the end of a long, empty corridor, Tales was drifting out of the adjacent storeroom, having completed his sweep of that section. For a breathtaking instant, they were separated by less than five feet and the thin, permeable barrier between the living and the dead. Tales felt a sudden, sharp spike in the ambient energy, a familiar signal of focused anxiety, but it was gone before he could triangulate it, lost in the echo of his own movement. Ben, his attention fixed on the recalcitrant lock, felt a sudden, inexplicable chill, a prickling on his skin that he dismissed as a draft from the building’s overzealous air conditioning. He finally turned the key, pushed the door open, and stepped inside, the heavy door swinging shut behind him.

He was safe. The quiet of the lab settled around him, a comforting blanket. His gaze went immediately to the mesh enclosure. Alistair was perched near the top, its head swiveling to watch him, a silent, living gargoyle. A small measure of the tension in Ben’s shoulders eased. This was real. This was manageable. But he was not alone. From the darkest corner of the room, a silent, unseen sentinel watched him. DI Tales had ceased his search. He had found his target. The three of them—the haunted, the hunter, and the ghost—were now together in the same small, sealed room, a fragile ecosystem of secrets and impending doom, while just outside the walls of the building, a patient, observant predator settled in for a long, watchful wait.The lab was Ben’s sanctuary, but it offered no peace. The silence was thick with unspoken fears. He moved with the jerky, inefficient motions of a man running on pure adrenaline and lack of sleep, his mind casting about for a task, any task, that could anchor him. The flimsy pretext that had brought him back here—ventilation—now seemed absurdly transparent even to himself. Still, he latched onto it. He found a small, battery-operated fan in a supply drawer and positioned it near the mesh-sided enclosure, angling it to create a gentle, indirect cross-breeze. It was a meaningless gesture, a nervous tic given physical form, but it was something to *do*. He watched the imperceptible movement of the air, then his gaze settled on Alistair. The mantis, oblivious, continued its patient grooming, a perfect, self-contained being of instinct and purpose. In its alien stillness, Ben saw a composure he desperately craved and knew he would never again possess.

From his corner, Tales watched this sad, busy-work ballet with a profound and aching pity. Ben was tending to a cage while the true predator circled the perimeter of his life, unseen and unheeded. The young man’s ignorance was a form of damnation. Tales could feel the frantic, scattered energy radiating from him, a psychic noise of guilt and confusion. A whispered word, a subtle suggestion—those were the tools of a diagnostician trying to guide a patient toward a realization. But the time for subtlety was over. This was an emergency. The patient was bleeding out and refusing to acknowledge the wound. Tales knew he had to attempt something more direct, a warning that could cut through the fog of Ben’s distress. It would be a monumental effort, a reckless expenditure of his fragile energy, but the alternative—to stand by and watch the inevitable unfold—was unthinkable.

Tonya’s patience was not infinite; it was simply calibrated to the demands of the hunt. Waiting outside the building was no longer yielding useful data. The specimen had retreated into its den, and passive observation from a distance was now insufficient. She needed to assess the nest itself, to understand the interior geography of his world. A small group of students, laughing and complaining about an upcoming exam, approached the entrance to the Hall of Sciences. Tonya recognized one of them from the department, a first-year she had seen in the company of Dr. Finch. Without a flicker of hesitation, she fell into step behind them, her gait adjusting to match their rhythm, her body language shifting to mimic their casual, collegiate slouch. She became one of them, a ghost in their machine. She passed through the doors as part of the group, a predator cloaked in the harmless colors of the herd, her cold, focused purpose a silent, deadly current in the warm stream of their oblivious lives.

Inside the lab, Ben had finally abandoned his pretense of activity and collapsed into his desk chair, his head in his hands. The low hum of the fan and the faint whir of his computer’s cooling system were the only sounds. It was in this moment of despairing quiet that Tales made his move. He gathered his will, focusing it with an intensity that felt like it might tear his very essence apart. He aimed not at Ben’s mind, but at the machine on his desk. He poured all his fear, his knowledge, and his desperate, screaming urgency into the sleeping screen of the computer. For a moment, nothing happened. Then, the screen flickered to life, not with its usual login prompt, but with a cascade of garbled, nonsensical characters, a river of digital gibberish. And in the very center of the chaos, for a single, shimmering second, a string of pixels coalesced into a recognizable shape. The letters were fractured, unstable, as if typed on a keyboard submerged in water: *Symm…ForJ…DANGER*.

Ben’s head snapped up at the sudden flash of light. He stared at the screen, his tired eyes struggling to process what they were seeing. The garbled text was already gone, replaced by the standard, placid blue of the login screen. He blinked. A power surge? A graphics card glitch? He rubbed his eyes, the image of the fractured words already fading, dismissed by his rational mind as a stress-induced hallucination, a phantom artifact of an exhausted brain. He sighed, shaking his head at his own frayed nerves, and turned his attention back to the mantis, missing the significance of the omen entirely. Tales, drained and ragged, felt a spectral wave of despair. He had fired his only warning shot, and it had been mistaken for a stray firework.

The hallways of the Hall of Sciences were a sterile, branching network, but Tonya navigated them with an unerring sense of direction. She moved with a quiet, fluid purpose, her eyes scanning the placards on the walls, her mind cross-referencing the information with the faculty directory she had memorized. She ignored the open doors of bustling lecture halls and the chatter spilling from common areas. She was drawn, as if by magnetism, to the quieter, more secluded corridors of the graduate research wing. The hum of the building was different here—less human, more mechanical. And then she saw it. At the end of a long, quiet hall, a simple plastic nameplate slid into a metal bracket. *B. Carter, Grad. Researcher*. The hunter had arrived at the door to the lair. She stood for a long moment, perfectly still, listening. She heard nothing but the faint, high-pitched whine of the building’s fluorescent lights. With a hand as steady as a surgeon’s, she reached out and rested her gloved fingers on the cool, smooth metal of the doorknob.The cool, smooth metal of the doorknob was a point of absolute reality. Tonya’s gloved fingers wrapped around it, and with a slow, deliberate motion born of infinite patience, she turned. The mechanism inside rotated, hit a point of resistance, and stopped. The door was locked. For a flicker of a moment, the world deviated from her plan, a slight, jarring imperfection in the flow of events. There was no surge of anger, no flicker of frustration in her expression. It was simply new data, a variable that required a revised approach. Forcing the door was a crude, asymmetrical solution, the method of a panicked animal like Ben. Her work required elegance, infiltration, a key. Her hand retreated from the knob, leaving no print, no evidence of her presence. She turned, her soft-soled shoes making no sound on the linoleum floor, and melted back into the quiet emptiness of the corridor. The objective had changed from passive observation to active acquisition.

Inside the lab, the almost imperceptible rattle of the knob was a sonic boom in the cathedral of Ben’s anxiety. He froze, his head snapping up from his hands, every nerve ending screaming. The sound was tiny, furtive, the antithesis of a casual colleague trying the door. His heart hammered against his ribs, a frantic, trapped bird. Was it Maya, forgetting something? Was it the building’s maintenance staff? Or was it her? Had she followed him? The sanctuary of the lab instantly transformed into a cage, a baited trap he had willingly walked into. Simultaneously, DI Tales, slumped in his spectral corner, felt it not as a sound but as a sudden, needle-sharp spike of cold intention pressing against the other side of the door. He felt the pure, predatory focus of Tonya Vance, and he felt the subsequent explosion of terror in Ben’s mind. The warning he had failed to deliver was now being announced by the turning of a lock, and it was a language Ben understood perfectly.

Slowly, silently, Ben pushed his chair back. He rose to his feet with the cautious, fluid movements of a prey animal that has sensed the predator at the edge of the clearing. He crept to the door, his own lab now a foreign and hostile territory. His eye went to the small, wire-reinforced glass window in the upper half of the door. He peered through, his breath held tight in his chest, expecting to see a face, a shadow, something. He saw nothing. The corridor was empty, sterile, bathed in the humming, indifferent light of the overhead fixtures. The absolute emptiness was a thousand times more terrifying than a confrontation. It was not his imagination. The sound had been real. She had been there. She had tested the door. And now she was gone. She knew where he was. The hunter had located his den, and now, somewhere in the labyrinth of the building, she was simply waiting.

The light was a clean, white scalpel. It sliced through the hushed dimness of the spare bedroom, pinning a single, struggling point of life to a square of polished obsidian. Under the unforgiving glare of the articulated lamp, *Formica rufa*, the red wood ant, soldiered on, its antennae twitching in a frantic semaphore of confusion and alarm. Tonya watched, her breath a slow, controlled tide in her chest. Her world had shrunk to this two-inch stage, this tiny drama of one. She wore no mask, but her face was as serene and immobile as a surgeon’s. Love required stillness. It demanded precision.

She’d followed this one for two days. A magnificent specimen. The slight, almost imperceptible asymmetry in its gaster, the subtle russet shading on its thorax—it was perfect in its imperfection. It was worthy. He would have liked this one. He would have spent an hour explaining its caste, its pheromonal language, the sheer evolutionary miracle of its existence. Tonya did not need the lecture anymore. She had absorbed it all, letting his knowledge colonize her, a new and sacred biome in the empty space he’d left behind. Now, she was the curator of his passion.

Her fingers, gloved in powder-free nitrile, moved with the unthinking grace of a concert pianist. She selected a pair of tweezers whose tips were ground to a near-molecular thinness. With a movement too swift for the ant to register, she nudged the tiny glass cloche covering it, creating a space just wide enough. The second instrument was a single human hair, plucked that morning, glued to the end of a delicate rod. She dipped its tip into a waiting bead of liquid glistening on a glass slide. Aconitine, extracted with painstaking effort from a single Wolf’s Bane plant she cultivated in a black pot on her windowsill. It was a poison of myth. A poet’s poison. It was fitting.

The ant, sensing the shift in air pressure, surged for the gap. Tonya was ready. The hair-tip applicator met the ant’s antenna in a kiss of shocking intimacy. The creature froze. A tremor, a violent, microscopic shudder, ran the length of its segmented body. Its legs, so full of frantic purpose a moment ago, curled inward. It was over. The stillness that followed was profound, a vacuum. Tonya felt it in her own lungs. She held her breath with the deceased, a shared, final exhalation.

Then, the second act. The art. She carefully transferred the tiny corpse to a block of black velvet, the same used by jewelers to display their finest solitaires. The posing was the most difficult part. It took an hour. Micro-forceps, stainless steel pins no thicker than a nerve ending, a magnifying visor that lowered over her eyes like a knight’s helmet. She worked to arrange it not in a posture of life, but in a posture of offering. Its head was tilted, its legs arranged in a pattern of submission. And then, the lips. She preferred the term ‘lips’ to ‘mandibles’. Mandibles was a cold, chitinous word. Lips were for kissing, for speaking, for tasting. With a tool of her own design, a tiny lever of sharpened dental wire, she gently, reverently, parted them.

The camera, a hulking Canon with a macro lens the size of a fist, was already in position. She leaned in, her eye to the viewfinder. The world vanished. There was only this. The alien, terrifying, beautiful architecture of the ant’s mouth. The serrated inner edges, the delicate palps, the textures invisible to the naked eye. It was a secret world. A world only she and he could ever truly appreciate. She adjusted the focus by a micron. The silence in the room was a held breath, waiting for a fever to break.

Click.

The shutter’s report was a soft, final punctuation. On the camera’s screen, the image bloomed. A landscape of dreadful intimacy. She had captured it. The essence. The last, silent word spoken from those lips. Another photograph for the collection. Another testament to a love so large it had to be expressed in the smallest of deaths.

From his non-place in the back corner of a Spokane library, the one on South Lincoln Street, DI Tales watched the image upload. It appeared on the photostream he monitored, a fresh wound among the old. The username was ‘SymmetryForJ.’ The photo was titled ‘Red Word.’ He felt the familiar, phantom chill, the one that had been his only constant companion for what felt like a lifetime. He was a doctor, or had been. He saw the world in terms of diagnosis. This was not art. This was a symptom.

The living moved around him like fish in a current he could not feel. A young woman with headphones on, her expression slack-jawed, walked through the space his left arm occupied. He felt nothing, of course. There was no substance to be disturbed. He was a draft of memory in a room full of warm bodies. He had long ago stopped flinching. His focus was absolute. He zoomed in on the image, not with a mouse and keyboard, but with a simple act of will. The picture filled his perception, a universe of texture and shadow.

‘SymmetryForJ.’ Tonya, he called her. He didn’t know her real name, but she felt like a Tonya. Solid, grounded, with a hint of Slavic tragedy in her bones. He’d built a profile in the empty chambers of his mind. Female, late 30s. Solitary. Highly intelligent, patient. Grieving. The ‘J’ was the key. J was the ghost she was trying to appease. The recipient of these macabre love letters.

Tales had been a diagnostician. He looked for patterns. At first, it was just the ants. Common Lasius niger. Then, the species began to diversify. Pavement ants. Carpenter ants. Now, Formica rufa, the red wood ant. The geography of her collection was expanding. The technique was improving, too. The early kills were clumsy, the carapaces sometimes crushed. Now, they were flawless. She was perfecting her craft. A surgeon honing her technique. The thought made the air in his non-lungs feel thin. Doctors, good ones, understood that a disease left untreated would metastasize. It would seek a larger host.

He had died on a Tuesday. A pulmonary embolism, silent and swift as an assassin. One moment he was complaining to his nurse, Martha, about the hospital’s dreadful coffee, the next he was… observing. Watching his own body slump in his chair, watching the panic, the futile CPR, the pronouncement. He had been a man of science and substance. He was now a hypothesis, a ghost story. And the most frustrating part of his condition was the impotence. He was a detective who could not lift a fingerprint, a doctor who could not touch his patient. He could only watch. And worry.

He sifted through the data of the new photograph. She was getting bolder. The background of ‘Red Word’ was not the familiar polished obsidian. It was a piece of dark, rough-hewn wood. He willed the image to expand again, focusing on a sliver of the background. He could make out the grain. The unique, swirling pattern of a burl. Oak, maybe? And in the corner, a tiny detail she would have missed. A watermark. A faint, almost invisible stamp. A logo. He couldn’t quite make it out. It was a circle with something inside. A bird? An initial?

He felt a surge of something that might have once been adrenaline. It was a lead. A tangible connection, however faint, to the physical world where she operated. He had to identify that mark. He had spent his life, his real one, solving puzzles inside the human body. This was no different. He was simply looking for the source of the infection. He had to find Tonya. He had to understand the shape of her love, the architecture of her grief. He had to stop her before she decided that ants were no longer enough. Before she looked for a larger vessel to hold all her terrible, beautiful devotion. The library was closing. The lights flickered once, a signal to the living. The patrons began to pack their bags, their movements solid and sure. Tales remained, a silent sentinel in the gathering dark, staring at a picture of a dead ant’s lips, feeling the cold, inexorable certainty that he was the only one who knew a storm was coming.

The janitor, a man named Gary whose weary slouch Tales had memorized like a medical chart, made his final round. His keys jangled a lonely, metallic tune as he locked the main doors, plunging the library into a cathedral-like quiet. For the living, the building was now empty. For Tales, it was finally his. He drifted from his corner, a silent eddy in the still air, and returned his full consciousness to the image of ‘Red Word.’ The physical screens had long since gone dark, but the image was seared into his perception, a slide under the microscope of his mind.

He pushed against the photograph, an act of pure will that had no physical correlation but felt like leaning into a strong wind. The watermark. The circle with the bird inside. The grain of the wood was a landscape of ridges and valleys, a topography he could almost feel. It was oak, he was almost certain, and the specific pattern was from a burl, a chaotic knot of growth that created the most beautiful, most unpredictable grains. J, the man for whom all this was done, must have appreciated such things. An appreciation for the complex beauty born from trauma and deviation. It was all of a piece. The imperfect ant, the burl wood, the grief that twisted love into this meticulous, murderous art.

His impotence was a physical ache, a phantom limb where his entire body used to be. In life, he would have been on the phone, delegating. He would have had a junior detective running license plates, an intern cross-referencing databases. He would have had his hands on the problem, palpating it for weaknesses. Now, he was reduced to this. A spectator, waiting for the world to bring him the clues he needed. The logo was a question he could not type into a search bar. He was a consciousness trapped in a bottle, and the entire internet, the greatest library in human history, was on the other side of the glass. He could only wait for someone else to turn the page.

* * *

After the final click, Tonya dismantled her world with the same reverence she had used to build it. The hulking Canon was powered down, its lens cap replaced with a soft thud. The tiny, posed corpse of the ant was transferred from the velvet block into a small glass-topped specimen box, which she labeled in a precise, architectural script: *Formica rufa, #27, Red Word*. It joined the others on a shelf in a temperature-controlled cabinet, a growing congregation of tiny martyrs. Each box was a votive, a prayer rendered in chitin and formaldehyde.

She stripped off the nitrile gloves, turning them inside out and sealing them in a small bag. Her tools were wiped down first with alcohol, then with a sterile cloth, before being laid back in their velvet-lined case. The tweezers, the micro-forceps, the hair-tip applicator, her custom-made mandible-lever—they all rested in their form-fitting depressions, an arsenal of delicate violence. The obsidian square and the velvet block were polished and put away. The last piece to be moved was the block of burl wood. She ran her bare fingers over its chaotic, swirling grain. J had given it to her. It was a cheese board, meant for brie and prosciutto and gatherings with friends. A lifetime ago. He’d bought it from a craftsman at a weekend market downtown. ‘Look at the grain, Tonya,’ he’d said, his voice buzzing with the excitement he found in the details of the world. ‘It’s like a map of a storm.’ Now, it was a stage. A beautiful, scarred landscape for her tragedies of one.

Her small apartment was a testament to a life distilled to its essentials. Clean, spartan, a single black pot on the windowsill where the Wolf’s Bane grew, its purple flowers a splash of royal poison against the grey Spokane sky. She didn’t eat here, not really. She didn’t entertain. She worked. She remembered. And she curated. She sat at her small desk and pulled up the photostream for ‘SymmetryForJ.’ She looked at ‘Red Word’ not as a photograph of a dead insect, but as a message sent into the ether. A message for an audience of one, who she knew could never see it. The intimacy of the image was the only way she could scream. The silence of her apartment was the only space vast enough to contain the echo.

* * *

The sun rose, casting long, dusty fingers of light through the library’s tall windows. The sounds of the city returned: the distant growl of traffic, the squeal of a bus’s air brakes. Then came the rattle of Gary’s keys, and the living began to trickle back in. Tales watched them, a current of purposeful bodies flowing around his stationary island of nothingness. A student, panicked about a deadline, raced to the history section. A homeless man, seeking warmth, settled into a carrel with a newspaper. A young mother steered her toddler towards the colourful promise of the children’s wing. They were all closed loops, preoccupied with their own narratives.

Tales drifted, a disembodied observer, his focus a hunter’s. He needed a specific kind of prey. Someone curious. Someone with a connection to craft, to wood, to local commerce. He floated behind a man in a flannel shirt who was poring over schematics for deck construction. For a moment, Tales felt a flicker of hope, but the man’s search was purely practical, his queries filled with terms like ‘load-bearing’ and ‘pressure-treated.’ He was not looking for art. Tales moved on. He had all the time in the world, a fact that was both a comfort and a curse. His own life had been a frantic race against the clock, against the progress of disease. Now, he was suspended in an endless, agonizing waiting room.

It was well past noon when he found her. A young woman with dark-rimmed glasses and a silver stud in her nose. She sat at a terminal in the reference section, surrounded by books on Pacific Northwest art. Her posture was studious, her brow furrowed in concentration. Tales positioned himself behind her, his non-physical form perfectly placed to see her screen. She was writing a paper, the title at the top of the document read: ‘From Totems to Tables: The Enduring Spirit of PNW Artisanship.’ He felt it again, that ghost of adrenaline. This was it. She typed, her fingers flying across the keyboard. Her search query was a gift from a god he no longer believed in: “local Spokane woodcraft artisans.” A page of results bloomed on the screen. A list of names and businesses. Tales scanned them, his focus narrowing. And then she clicked on a link. The website loaded, and the logo appeared, crisp and clear in the top left corner. A perfect circle. And inside, a stylized bird—a wren, he now saw—with its head cocked, its beak forming the cross-bar of a capital ‘B’. Below it, the words: ‘Burl & Beak Woodcraft.’ He had it. He had a name. It was a tangible piece of the world, a pin dropped on a map. For the first time since he had died, DI Tales had a destination. Now he just had to find a way to get there.

The library was a cage, elegant and quiet, but a cage nonetheless. For weeks, or months—time had become a viscous, unreliable fluid—Tales had accepted its boundaries as the limits of his new reality. The world outside the tall arched windows was a silent film he could observe but not join. But now, with a name and a logo burned into his mind, the library’s familiar silence felt like a suffocating pressure. ‘Burl & Beak Woodcraft.’ It was a location. A place of substance and sawdust, a place where Tonya had been. To a ghost, a physical coordinate was an impossible, taunting dream.

His attention snapped back to the young woman with the dark-rimmed glasses. She was his only chance. He watched as she saved her document, closed the browser tabs, and began to gather her belongings with the unhurried movements of someone whose day was winding down. A canvas tote bag, a dented metal water bottle, a worn copy of a book on forestry. Each item was a solid, real thing, a piece of a world he could no longer manipulate. She was his vessel, his unwitting ferryman. He had to try. He had spent his first life diagnosing the frailties of the human body; he would spend his second diagnosing the physics of his own dissolution.

He marshaled his focus, a power he was only beginning to understand. It felt like holding his breath and flexing a muscle that wasn't there. He concentrated everything he was, his memory, his worry, his fading identity, into a single point of intention aimed directly at her. As she slung the tote bag over her shoulder and began to walk towards the main exit, Tales pushed off from his corner, not moving through the air so much as willing himself to be adjacent to her. He felt a strange, elastic pull, as if he had become a satellite caught in the faint gravitational field of her life force.

The automatic doors slid open with a soft hiss, and the student stepped out into the late afternoon light. Tales followed, and the world exploded. For the first time since his death, he was outside. The sensory onslaught was a physical blow. The muted, dusty air of the library was replaced by a riot of smells: hot asphalt, diesel exhaust, the sweet, cloying scent of a flowering bush nearby. The quiet hum of the library’s HVAC system was annihilated by the roar of a passing bus, its immense vibration passing through his formless state like a shockwave, leaving him feeling frayed and scattered. The sunlight was not the gentle, slanted beam he was used to, but a brilliant, brutal glare that seemed to make his own transparency shimmer and thin.

He fought to hold on. The pull to the student, his anchor, was the only thing that kept him from dissolving entirely or snapping back to the safe, dead quiet of the library. He was a kite in a hurricane, and she was the hand holding the string. She put her headphones on, oblivious, and crossed at the light, her head bobbing to a beat he couldn't hear. A cyclist swerved around her, and for a terrifying second, passed directly through Tales. The rush of kinetic energy and the fleeting, phantom sensation of a living, straining body was so alien, so overwhelming, that his concentration wavered. The world flickered, and for a half-second, he saw the familiar shelves of the library’s biography section superimposed over the moving traffic. He clamped down with his will, the effort a silent scream. The street solidified around him again.

He was a parasite of perception, clinging to her as she walked west on Main Avenue. He didn't know where ‘Burl & Beak’ was. His knowledge of the city was a static memory from a life that felt increasingly like someone else’s. He couldn't ask for directions. He couldn't pull a phone from a pocket that didn't exist and look at a map. He could only follow this oblivious stranger and pray that her path would bring him within range. With a final, desperate act of will, he focused everything he was—the sum of his memories, his methodical mind, the full weight of his concern for the unknown Tonya—on the wooden sign. The workshop was a sanctuary of potential. Unlike the library, which was a repository of finished thoughts and closed histories, this place hummed with a silent, vibrant future. A door at the back of the showroom creaked open, and a man emerged from the dust-filled workshop beyond. The man’s finger hovered over a file labeled ‘Spokane Weekend Market – Sales.’ Tales felt the phantom charge of adrenaline again. J had bought the board at a market. This was the right vein.

The man opened the file. A list of transactions appeared, dated a little over a year ago. It was a long list, a successful weekend. The craftsman scrolled slowly, his brow furrowed slightly as he reconciled the numbers. Tales’s perception devoured the screen, scanning names and item descriptions. *Cedar Box. Walnut Bowl. Cherry Spoon Set.* He saw names—Miller, Chen, Rodriguez—a litany of the living, the solid, the people who could buy things and take them home. He searched for a Tonya, a T., anything. Nothing. Then the man’s finger stopped. He tapped on a line, expanding it. Item: *Oak Burl Round Board, 12”*. Date: a Saturday in late May. And there, under ‘Customer,’ was the name. It wasn’t Tonya. It was a simple, elegant entry: J. Alistair Finch. Below it was an email address. J.A.Finch@spokane.edu.

Spokane University. It was another pin on the map, a place miles away. He had learned to jump, but it had nearly shredded him. Now, he had to figure out how to fly.

The elation was a flash of heat, a magnesium flare that burned brightly for a moment before sputtering out, leaving behind the cold, grey ash of his reality. J. Alistair Finch. Spokane University. The information was a key, but he was standing on the wrong side of a locked and soundproofed door. The woodshop, once a thrilling destination, now felt like another room in his prison. He drifted to the front window, his form shimmering in the afternoon sun. The lane outside was quiet, but at its mouth, the main street was a river of metal and intention. Leaving the sanctuary of Burl & Beak was just as jarring as his first exit from the library. He braced himself, focusing on the bus as his target, and pushed through the window. Tonya sat in the dimness of her spare bedroom, the sacred space. The photograph of ‘Red Word’ glowed on her monitor. It was, by all technical measures, perfect. The university campus was a world unto itself. Unlike the weary, transient energy of the bus, this place thrummed with a nervous, ambitious vitality. His will, a newly discovered and subtle instrument, prodded at the mind of the student staring at the screen. Back at the university, Tales had a name and a destination, a combination that felt both potent and useless. The new stage was a glass cube, a miniature world of soil, moss, and tangled branches. Tonya had spent the afternoon constructing it, her movements as deliberate as a god designing a habitat. The journey east was a disembodying experience for a being already without a body. The dense tapestry of human life that made up the city thinned out, leaving Tales feeling exposed and fragile. The first sign of Palouse Falls was not a sight but a sound, a low, persistent roar that grew from a whisper on the edge of hearing to a deep, chest-vibrating thunder.
